title: Copy-cat? Youth with few friends conform to stay in a friend's 'good graces': Study tests the theory that children with few friends protect these friendships through conformity
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=What gives one friend influence over another? Considerable attention has focused on who influences whom; much less is known about why one partner is prone to be influenced by the other. A study tested the hypothesis that within a friend dyad, having fewer friends than one's partner increases susceptibility to influence, because it reduces dissimilarity and promotes compatibility. Results showed that partners with fewer friends were influenced by children with more friends. In each case, the partner with fewer friends became more similar to the partner with more friends. Academic engagement was the only domain where partners with fewer friends also influenced partners with more friends.&title=Copy-cat? Youth with few friends conform to stay in a friend's 'good graces': Study tests the theory that children with few friends protect these friendships through conformity&link=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2023/02/230207091843.htm&picture=https://i.pinimg.com/originals/72/9a/78/729a78324d23a4235750e34159f4127e.jpg&longDescription=Peer influence is pervasive during childhood and adolescence. Conformity can foster similarity, which makes it easier to get along and reduces the risk that disagreements over dissimilarities will rupture a friendship. Seen in this light, conformity is an effective strategy for appeasing friends and maintaining the potentially hard to replace benefits the friendship provides.

title: Researchers detail never-before-seen properties in a family of superconducting Kagome metals
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Researchers have used an innovative new strategy combining nuclear magnetic resonance imaging and a quantum modeling theory to describe the microscopic structure of Kagome superconductor RbV3Sb5 at 103 degrees Kelvin, which is equivalent to about 275 degrees below 0 degrees Fahrenheit.&title=Researchers detail never-before-seen properties in a family of superconducting Kagome metals&link=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2023/02/230210185152.htm&picture=https://scx1.b-cdn.net/csz/news/800a/2023/researchers-detail-nev.jpg&longDescription=Researchers have used an innovative new strategy combining nuclear magnetic resonance imaging and a quantum modeling theory to describe the microscopic structure of Kagome superconductor RbV3Sb5 at 103 degrees Kelvin, which is equivalent to about 275 degrees below 0 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Brain structural differences observed in children with conduct disorder with and without childhood maltreatment
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Characterized by antisocial behaviors and low academic achievement, conduct disorder (CD) impacts an estimated 9.5% of individuals in the United States. Childhood maltreatment is a major risk factor for CD. Past CD studies have identified structural alterations in various brain regions, such as those implicated in emotion processing, learning, and social cognition. A new study has now assessed whether youths with CD who experienced childhood maltreatment differ at the brain level from those with CD without a history of maltreatment.&title=Brain structural differences observed in children with conduct disorder with and without childhood maltreatment&link=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2023/02/230207144227.htm&picture=https://m.media-amazon.com/images/I/51Q1lw0pfwL._SL10_UR1600,800_CR200,50,1200,630_CLa%7C1200,630%7C51Q1lw0pfwL.jpg%7C0,0,1200,630+107,79,402,402_PJAdblSocialShare-Gradientoverlay-smallasin-0to70,TopLeft,0,0_PJAdblSocialShare-AudibleLogo-Large,TopLeft,576,270_OU01_ZBLISTENING%20ON,593,216,52,500,AudibleSansMd,30,255,255,255_PJAdblSocialShare-PodcastIcon-Small,TopLeft,1094,50_ZBBrain%20Structural%20Differ...,106,519,48,404,AudibleSansMd,24,255,255,255.jpg&longDescription=Characterized by antisocial behaviors and low academic achievement, conduct disorder (CD) impacts an estimated 9.5% of individuals in the United States. Childhood maltreatment is a major risk factor for CD. Past CD studies have identified structural alterations in various brain regions, such as those implicated in emotion processing, learning, and social cognition. A new study has now assessed whether youths with CD who experienced childhood maltreatment differ at the brain level from those with CD without a history of maltreatment.

title: A new ring system discovered in our Solar System

url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Scientists have discovered a new ring system around a dwarf planet on the edge of the Solar System. title: Hubble captures the start of a new spoke season at Saturn
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Since their discovery by NASA's Voyager mission in the 1980s, temporary 'spoke' features across Saturn's rings have fascinated scientists, yet eluded explanation. They have been observed in the years preceding and following the planet's equinox, becoming more prominent as the date approaches. Saturn's upcoming autumnal equinox of the northern hemisphere on May 6, 2025, means that spoke season has come again. NASA's Hubble Space Telescope will be on the job studying the spokes, thanks to time dedicated to Saturn in the mission's ongoing Outer Planet Atmospheres Legacy (OPAL) program. Are the smudgy features related to Saturn's magnetic field and its interaction with the solar wind, as prevailing theory suggests? Confirmation could come in this spoke season, as scientists combine archival data from NASA's Cassini mission with new Hubble observations.&title=Hubble captures the start of a new spoke season at Saturn&link=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2023/02/230209094205.htm&picture=https://images.hindustantimes.com/tech/img/2023/02/12/960x540/hubble3b_1671872217798_1676174494635_1676174494635.jpg&longDescription=Since their discovery by NASA's Voyager mission in the 1980s, temporary 'spoke' features across Saturn's rings have fascinated scientists, yet eluded explanation. They have been observed in the years preceding and following the planet's equinox, becoming more prominent as the date approaches. Saturn's upcoming autumnal equinox of the northern hemisphere on May 6, 2025, means that spoke season has come again. NASA's Hubble Space Telescope will be on the job studying the spokes, thanks to time dedicated to Saturn in the mission's ongoing Outer Planet Atmospheres Legacy (OPAL) program. Are the smudgy features related to Saturn's magnetic field and its interaction with the solar wind, as prevailing theory suggests? Confirmation could come in this spoke season, as scientists combine archival data from NASA's Cassini mission with new Hubble observations.

title: Time of day may determine the amount of fat burned by exercise
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Physical activity at the right time of the day seems able to increase fat metabolism, at least in mice. title: A more healthful, gluten-free flour made from sweet potatoes
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Orange, starchy sweet potatoes are great mashed, cut into fries or just roasted whole. But you likely haven't considered grinding them into a flour and baking them into your next batch of cookies -- or at least, not yet! Recent research has reported the best method to turn sweet potatoes into gluten-free flours that are packed with antioxidants and perfect for thickening or baking.&title=A more healthful, gluten-free flour made from sweet potatoes&link=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2023/02/230213082154.htm&picture=https://scx2.b-cdn.net/gfx/news/hires/2023/a-more-healthful-glute.jpg&longDescription=Orange, starchy sweet potatoes are great mashed, cut into fries or just roasted whole. But you likely haven't considered grinding them into a flour and baking them into your next batch of cookies -- or at least, not yet! Recent research has reported the best method to turn sweet potatoes into gluten-free flours that are packed with antioxidants and perfect for thickening or baking.

title: Review strengthens evidence that repetitive head impacts can cause CTE
author: Saint-Minion
url: https://hannaconsultantgroup.com/max/adds.html?description=Over 600 CTE cases have been published in the literature from multiple international research groups. And of those over 600 cases, 97 percent have confirmed exposure to RHI, primarily through contact and collision sports. CTE has been diagnosed in amateur and professional athletes, including athletes from American, Canadian, and Australian football, rugby union, rugby league, soccer, ice hockey, bull-riding, wrestling, mixed-martial arts, and boxing.&title=Review strengthens evidence that repetitive head impacts can cause CTE&link=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2023/02/230210115511.htm&picture=https://scx1.b-cdn.net/csz/news/800a/2023/review-strengthens-evi.jpg&longDescription=Over 600 CTE cases have been published in the literature from multiple international research groups. And of those over 600 cases, 97 percent have confirmed exposure to RHI, primarily through contact and collision sports. CTE has been diagnosed in amateur and professional athletes, including athletes from American, Canadian, and Australian football, rugby union, rugby league, soccer, ice hockey, bull-riding, wrestling, mixed-martial arts, and boxing.
